title.value: CKGConv: General Graph Convolution with Continuous Kernels
title.justification: This is the title found at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: CKGConv: General Graph Convolution with Continuous Kernels

extractions.description: The paper presents Continuous Kernel Graph Convolution (CKGConv), a novel and general graph convolution framework by parameterizing the kernels as continuous functions of pseudo-coordinates derived via graph positional encoding. It demonstrates that CKGConv is flexible, expressive, and can outperform existing graph convolutional networks while performing comparably to state-of-the-art graph transformers across various graph datasets.

type.justification: The paper includes theoretical demonstrations alongside empirical experiments and results, showing the effectiveness of the proposed CKGConv framework in various scenarios.
type.quote: Empirically, we show that CKGConv-based Networks outperform existing graph convolutional networks and perform comparably to the best graph transformers across a variety of graph datasets.

name.justification: The paper proposes a new convolutional framework specifically designed for graph structures and evaluates its performance against other graph convolutional networks and graph transformers.
name.quote: We propose a novel and general graph convolution framework by parameterizing the kernels as continuous functions of pseudo-coordinates derived via graph positional encoding.

name.justification: The proposed model, CKGConv, is a type of graph convolutional network aimed at addressing limitations in existing GCNs.
name.quote: We show that CKGConv-based Networks outperform existing graph convolutional networks.

name.justification: The paper compares the expressiveness and performance of CKGConv against graph transformers, showing that it performs comparably on various benchmarks.
name.quote: CKGConv-based Networks ... perform comparably to the best graph transformers across a variety of graph datasets.

name.justification: CKGConv is the main model proposed and evaluated in the paper.
name.quote: We name this Continuous Kernel Graph Convolution (CKGConv).

is_contributed.justification: CKGConv is introduced as a novel contribution in the paper.
is_contributed.quote: We propose a novel and general graph convolution framework by parameterizing the kernels as continuous functions of pseudo-coordinates derived via graph positional encoding. We name this Continuous Kernel Graph Convolution (CKGConv).

is_executed.justification: Empirical evaluations of CKGConv indicate that the models were executed on hardware, likely involving both CPU and GPU usage during various experiments although specific mention of hardware isn't explicitly found in the quotes.
is_executed.quote: Empirically, we show that CKGConv-based Networks outperform existing graph convolutional networks.

is_compared.justification: CKGConv-based Networks are compared to existing graph convolutional networks and graph transformers in terms of performance.
is_compared.quote: Empirically, we show that CKGConv-based Networks outperform existing graph convolutional networks and perform comparably to the best graph transformers across a variety of graph datasets.

referenced_paper_title.justification: CKGConv is introduced in this paper, hence there is no prior referenced paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We propose a novel and general graph convolution framework ... We name this Continuous Kernel Graph Convolution (CKGConv).

name.justification: ZINC is one of the datasets used to evaluate the performance of the CKGConv model.
name.quote: We evaluate our proposed method on five datasets from Benchmarking GNNs (Dwivedi et al., 2022a) and another two datasets from Long-Range Graph Benchmark (Dwivedi et al., 2022c). These benchmarks include diverse node-and graph-level learning tasks such as node classification, graph classification, and graph regression.
